choices.text: Central perforation in the anteroinferior quadrant
Granulations and red fleshy polyps are common

questions.text: All of the following are features of attico-antral type of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM), except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Central perforation in the anteroinferior quadrant

 

Because central perforation in the anteroinferior quadrant is characteristic of the tubo-tympanic (safe) type of CSOM, not attico-antral.

 

Attico-antral CSOM is the unsafe type, usually involving the attic or posterior-superior part of the tympanic membrane.


It is characterized by marginal/attic perforation, cholesteatoma, granulations, and foul-smelling discharge.


The disease causes bone erosion with risk of serious extracranial and intracranial complications.


Surgery (mastoidectomy) is the definitive treatment to achieve a safe, dry ear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Also called the unsafe type: True. Attico-antral disease is considered unsafe because of risk of serious complications (mastoiditis, facial palsy, intracranial spread).

 

Option B. Cholesteatoma is present: True. Cholesteatoma (keratinizing squamous epithelium in middle ear) is a hallmark of attico-antral CSOM, leading to bone erosion.

 

Option D. Granulations and red fleshy polyps are common: True. Granulation tissue and aural polyps often accompany the chronic inflammatory process in unsafe type CSOM.

choices.text: Inflammation is restricted anterior to the orbital septum
Ethmoidal sinusitis is the most common source of infection in all age groups
Topical broad-spectrum antibiotics are the first line of management
Patient presents with proptosis, blurring of vision, normal pupillary and ocular movement

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding orbital cellulitis is true:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ethmoidal sinusitis is the most common source of infection in all age groups

 

Orbital cellulitis is an infection of tissues that lie posterior to the orbital septum. The most common cause is spread from paranasal sinus infections, particularly the ethmoid sinus because of the thin lamina papyracea. This is true for both children and adults, making option B correct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inflammation is restricted anterior to the orbital septum: This describes preseptal cellulitis, not orbital cellulitis. In orbital cellulitis, the infection extends beyond the septum into the orbit.

 

Option C. Topical broad-spectrum antibiotics are the first line of management: This is incorrect because orbital cellulitis is a serious, potentially life-threatening condition. It requires systemic intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics and sometimes surgical drainage, not just topical therapy.

 

Option D. Patient presents with proptosis, blurring of vision, normal pupillary and ocular movement: This is also incorrect. In orbital cellulitis, patients usually present with proptosis, painful or restricted eye movements, decreased vision, and sometimes abnormal pupillary reactions such as RAPD. Normal motility is not a feature.

questions.text: In acute suppurative otitis media, during which phase is the ear pain at its peak intensity?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stage of suppuration

 

In acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM), the disease progresses through well-defined stages.

 

  • During the stage of suppuration, pus collects in the middle ear cavity, leading to marked rise in middle ear pressure.
  • This pressure stretches the tympanic membrane to its maximum, making it intensely congested and bulging.
  • At this stage, the patient experiences severe, throbbing ear pain at its peak intensity.

 

 

Stages of ASOM are:

 

1. Stage of Tubal Occlusion

 

  • Eustachian tube blockage
  • Negative middle ear pressure
  • Retraction of tympanic membrane

 

2. Stage of Pre-suppuration (Hyperemia / Congestion Stage)

 

  • Middle ear mucosa congested and edematous
  • Tympanic membrane congested, opaque
  • Mild to moderate ear pain begins

 

3. Stage of Suppuration

 

  • Pus formation in middle ear
  • Tympanic membrane bulges, highly congested
  • Severe, throbbing ear pain at its peak
  • Conductive hearing loss

 

4. Stage of Resolution (Perforation Stage)

 

  • Tympanic membrane perforates
  • Purulent discharge appears, pain suddenly relieved
  • Hearing loss persists but less pain

questions.text: A 30-year-old school teacher presents with a three-day history of fever, chills, and sore throat. He also complains of difficulty swallowing that started yesterday. He denies any cough, chest pain, or difficulty breathing. His temperature is 39.8° C (102.2 F), blood pressure is 118/76 mmHg, pulse is 102/min, and respirations are 19/min. On examination, his voice is muffled. Enlarged, tender cervical lymph nodes are palpated on the left, and his uvula is deviated to the right. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Needle peritonsillar aspiration

 

This patient presents with fever, sore throat, dysphagia, muffled “hot potato” voice, tender cervical lymphadenopathy, and uvular deviation – classical signs of a peritonsillar abscess (quinsy).

 

  • The uvula deviates away from the side of the abscess due to tonsillar swelling.
  • The standard treatment is drainage of the abscess, which can be done by needle aspiration, incision and drainage, or tonsillectomy (quinsy tonsillectomy in select cases).
  • Needle aspiration is the first-line and most appropriate immediate management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Throat swabs and oral antibiotics: This is insufficient. A peritonsillar abscess requires drainage; antibiotics alone cannot resolve the pus collection.

 

Option B. Monospot test and oral antibiotics: This is used to diagnose infectious mononucleosis caused by EBV. The clinical picture here (uvular deviation, muffled voice) is more consistent with peritonsillar abscess, not mono.

 

Option C. Emergency laryngoscopy: Indicated in suspected airway obstruction, such as epiglottitis or severe laryngeal pathology. This patient has no stridor or severe respiratory distress, so laryngoscopy is not the initial step.

choices.text: It may lead to pugilistic ear
It is caused by accumulation of blood in perichondrial space
All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotics

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presented at the hospital with a reported history of ear trauma. Upon examination, there was observed swelling, tenderness, and discoloration of the ear. Which of the following is false regarding the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Resolves spontaneously

 

Auricular hematoma = collection of blood between the perichondrium and cartilage of the pinna due to trauma.


If not treated, it organizes into fibrous tissue and deforms the ear → cauliflower ear (pugilistic ear).

 

  • It does not resolve spontaneously. Instead, it requires drainage and compression.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. It may lead to pugilistic ear: true. Untreated hematoma causes fibrosis and cartilage distortion → cauliflower ear, typical in boxers/wrestlers.

 

Option B. It is caused by accumulation of blood in perichondrial space: true. Trauma separates perichondrium from underlying cartilage, blood fills this space.

 

Option D. All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotics: true. Because cartilage has poor blood supply, hematomas are prone to infection and perichondritis. Prophylactic antistaphylococcal antibiotics are recommended.

choices.text: Facial nerve proximal to geniculate ganglion
Facial nerve at the vertical segment of ear

questions.text: A woman presents with a history of sudden spontaneous lacrimation upon salivation. The lesion behind this pathology is located at:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Facial nerve proximal to geniculate ganglion

 

The woman has crocodile tears syndrome (Bogorad’s syndrome), where there is abnormal lacrimation while eating (salivation-induced tearing).

 

  • It occurs due to misdirected regeneration of facial nerve fibers after injury.
  • Normally, fibers to the submandibular/sublingual glands via the chorda tympani are redirected to the greater petrosal nerve fibers supplying the lacrimal gland.
  • This happens only if the lesion is proximal to the geniculate ganglion, because that is where both chorda tympani (taste/parasympathetic) and greater petrosal (lacrimation) pathways branch.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chorda tympani in infratemporal fossa: Not correct. Lesion here would cause loss of taste to anterior 2/3 tongue and reduced salivation, but lacrimal misdirection cannot occur as greater petrosal fibers have already branched off earlier.

 

Option C. Facial nerve at stylomastoid foramen: Not correct. This lesion only affects motor fibers to facial muscles. Lacrimation and salivation remain unaffected.

 

Option D. Facial nerve at the vertical segment of ear: Not correct. A lesion here can cause hyperacusis and facial palsy, but crocodile tears occur only when the lesion is more proximal, before the geniculate ganglion.

questions.text: Indication for this incision:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Open rhinoplasty

 

The image shows a transcolumellar incision (visible at the columella between the nostrils) joined with bilateral marginal incisions inside the alae.

 

  • This combined approach is the open rhinoplasty incision.
  • It provides wide exposure of nasal structures (cartilage, septum, dorsum) for correction of cosmetic or functional nasal deformities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Caldwell Luc: This is an approach for maxillary sinus surgery. The incision is made in the gingivobuccal sulcus above the canine fossa, not on the columella.

 

 

Option B. Midfacial degloving: This incision is used for access to midfacial skeleton, nasal cavity, and paranasal sinuses. It involves sublabial incision and intranasal incisions, not the transcolumellar incision.

 

 

Option D. SMR (Submucous Resection of septum): Here, the incision is usually Killian’s incision made inside the nasal cavity over the septal mucosa, not visible externally.

questions.text: Which of these is an indication for giving adjuvant radiotherapy in oral malignancy after resection and MRND?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Extranodal extension

 

The image shows a patient post oral cancer resection with Modified Radical Neck Dissection (MRND). After surgical treatment, the decision for adjuvant radiotherapy (RT) is guided by high-risk pathological features.

 

  • Extranodal extension (ENE) = tumor spread beyond the capsule of involved lymph nodes.
  • This is considered a high-risk feature, and adjuvant radiotherapy (or chemoradiotherapy) is mandatory, as it significantly increases the chance of local-regional recurrence if untreated.

 

Criteria for Adjuvant Radiotherapy: Primary Tumor

 

  • Surgical margins less than 5 mm
  • Additional considerations:
    • Low-grade cellular differentiation
    • Evidence of nerve involvement
    • Tumor cells present in blood vessels or lymphatics
    • Significant depth of invasion

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple lymph node metastases: This is an intermediate-risk feature. Adjuvant RT may be considered, but it is not an absolute indication unless associated with ENE.

 

Option C. T3 tumor: Tumor stage T3 is also an intermediate-risk factor. It may require RT depending on margin status and nodal disease, but not always mandatory.

 

Option D. LN Size >3 cm: Large node size alone is not an absolute indication unless there is extranodal extension.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with worsening fever and sore throat. Four days ago, the patient accidentally swallowed a fish bone that scratched her throat and caused some discomfort. She felt better after some time and did not seek medical attention, but for the past 2 days she has had severe sore throat and difficulty swallowing. The patient also reports neck pain and stiffness. Examination shows pooling of saliva in the hypopharynx. The posterior pharyngeal wall is red and bulging. The neck is stiff with reduced passive range of motion. Lung auscultation is normal. Lateral radiographs of the neck reveal increased thickness of the prevertebral soft tissues with an air-fluid level. Due to potential contiguous spread of the disease process, this patient is at greatest risk of developing which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. ﻿A) Acute necrotizing mediastinitis

 

  • The scenario describes a classic case of retropharyngeal abscess, which can develop after a traumatic event such as swallowing a sharp foreign object that injures the posterior pharyngeal wall.
  • Findings: Severe sore throat, pooling of saliva, bulging posterior pharyngeal wall, neck pain, and prevertebral soft tissue swelling with air-fluid level on lateral neck X-ray are hallmark features of retropharyngeal abscess.
  • This abscess is located in the retropharyngeal space, which is anatomically continuous with the mediastinum via the "danger space" (between alar and prevertebral fascia). Because of this, infection can easily spread downward into the mediastinum, causing acute necrotizing mediastinitis, a life-threatening complication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cranial subdural empyema: Typically results from contiguous spread of sinusitis or otitis, not from retropharyngeal infections.

 

Option C. Ludwig angina: Involves the submandibular space, often originating from dental infections, not retropharyngeal abscess.

 

Option D. Septic cavernous sinus thrombosis: Most commonly occurs secondary to infections of the face, nose, or sinuses, not the posterior pharyngeal wall.

choices.text: Positive skin test for inhaled allergens

questions.text: A woman develops wheezing after taking aspirin for a headache. Which statement is true about this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Associated with ethmoid polyps

 

  • Aspirin-induced asthma (Aspirin-Exacerbated Respiratory Disease, AERD/Samter’s triad) is classically associated with asthma, nasal polyps (especially ethmoid), and aspirin sensitivity.
  • This is not a type of extrinsic (allergic) asthma. Skin tests for inhaled allergens are typically negative, and serum IgE levels are not consistently elevated.
  • Ethmoid (and other nasal) polyps are a distinguishing feature of AERD and help separate it from other asthma subtypes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type of extrinsic asthma:

 

  • This is incorrect because AERD is not a type of extrinsic (allergic) asthma.
  • Extrinsic asthma is IgE-mediated and triggered by allergens.
  • AERD is a non-IgE-mediated, non-allergic asthma caused by abnormal metabolism of arachidonic acid leading to leukotriene overproduction after NSAID exposure.
  • This means it does not involve typical allergic sensitization pathways.

 

Option B. Raised serum IgE levels:

 

  • Typically, serum IgE is not elevated in AERD because the disease is not an allergic IgE-mediated reaction.
  • However, some studies have shown that a subset of AERD patients may have elevated total IgE without classic atopy, but this is not a defining feature of the disease.
  • The predominant mechanism relates to dysregulated mast cell activation and leukotriene production rather than IgE antibodies.

 

Option D. Positive skin test for inhaled allergens:

 

  • Skin tests for inhaled allergens are usually negative in AERD patients.
  • This is because AERD is not triggered by common environmental allergens but by cyclooxygenase inhibition from aspirin/NSAIDs.
  • Unlike extrinsic asthma, AERD’s pathophysiology involves leukotriene-mediated inflammation rather than allergen-specific IgE responses.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements about pediatric airway:

 

  1. Epiglottis moves up during swallowing 
  2. They can suckle and breathe at the same time 
  3. Larynx opposite C3-C6
  4. Narrowest portion is at the level of cricoid cartilage 
  5. Epiglottis is shorter and wider
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 4

 

Statement 1. Epiglottis moves up during swallowing: Correct. In infants and children, the epiglottis is relatively high and helps in preventing aspiration. During swallowing, it elevates to protect the airway from food entry.

 

Statement 2. They can suckle and breathe at the same time: Correct. Infants are considered “obligate nasal breathers” up to around 6 months. The high position of the larynx allows them to breathe while suckling.

 

Statement 4. Narrowest portion is at the level of cricoid cartilage: Correct. In pediatrics (especially under 5 years), the airway is funnel-shaped, and the cricoid cartilage is the narrowest part, unlike in adults where it is the vocal cords.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 3. Larynx opposite C3–C6: Incorrect. In infants, the larynx is higher, usually opposite C2–C3. It descends gradually to adult level (C5–C6).

 

Statement 5. Epiglottis is shorter and wider: Incorrect. Pediatric epiglottis is actually longer, narrower, and more omega-shaped (floppy) compared to adults.

questions.text: A patient presented with odynophagia and cervical lymphadenopathy. On examination, ulcerated growth was present on base of tongue which was found to be squamous cell carcinoma. What is the most common organism associated?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HPV

 

Human Papilloma Virus (HPV), especially HPV-16, is strongly associated with oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma, particularly involving the base of tongue and tonsils.

 

  • These cancers are increasing in incidence, especially in younger, non-smoking patients.
  • HPV-positive oropharyngeal cancers tend to have better prognosis compared to HPV-negative ones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): 

 

  • Not associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the base of tongue.
  • More relevant in immunocompromised states (eg, HIV, transplant recipients) where it causes esophagitis or retinitis, not carcinoma.

 

Option C. EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus): 

 

  • Associated with nasopharyngeal carcinoma, not with tongue base squamous carcinoma.
  • Also linked to Burkitt’s lymphoma and Hodgkin’s lymphoma.

 

Option D. HSV (Herpes Simplex Virus): 

 

  • Causes painful oral ulcers and herpetic stomatitis.
  • No strong link with oral/oropharyngeal squamous carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • HPV → Oropharyngeal carcinoma (tonsil, base of tongue) & laryngeal carcinoma
  • EBV → Nasopharyngeal carcinoma

choices.text: Inferior border of infraorbital rim and superior border of external auditory canal
Superior border of infraorbital rim and superior border of external auditory canal
Inferior border of infraorbital rim and inferior border of external auditory canal
Superior border of infraorbital rim and inferior border of external auditory canal

questions.text: Identify the correct plane of Frankfurt horizontal plane:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inferior border of infraorbital rim and superior border of external auditory canal

 

  • The Frankfurt Horizontal Plane (FHP) is a standard anatomical reference plane used in anthropology, orthodontics, and radiology.
  • It is defined by a line joining:
    • Inferior border of the infraorbital rim (orbitale) → lowest point on the infraorbital margin.
    • Superior border of the external auditory canal (porion) → uppermost point on the ear canal opening.
  • This plane represents the natural head position and is used as a baseline in cephalometry and skull measurements.

questions.text:
Arrange in correct order of cervical VEMP:

 

  1. Saccule 
  2. Utricle
  3. Superior vestibular nerve
  4. Inferior vestibular nerve
  5. Vestibular nucleus 
  6. SCM 
  7. MLF
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-4-5-6

 

The cervical Vestibular Evoked Myogenic Potential (cVEMP) is a reflex pathway that tests saccular and inferior vestibular nerve function, recorded from the sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle.

 

The correct pathway is:

 

1. Saccule: origin of the reflex, sensitive to sound.

 

4. Inferior vestibular nerve: carries impulses from the saccule.

 

5. Vestibular nucleus: integration center in the brainstem.

 

6. Sternocleidomastoid muscle: inhibitory reflex recorded here.

 

Thus, the correct sequence = 1 → 4 → 5 → 6.

 

2. Cervical VEMP (cVEMP): Evaluates the saccule and inferior vestibular nerve by recording responses from the sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle.

 

3. Ocular VEMP (oVEMP): Assesses the utricle and superior vestibular nerve by measuring responses from muscles near the C/L eyes (typically the inferior oblique).

questions.text:
Nystagmus to the opposite side of the lesion occurs in:

 

  1. Purulent labyrinthitis
  2. Trauma to labyrinth
  3. Serous labyrinthitis
  4. Hypoactive labyrinth
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 4

 

  • Nystagmus in Labyrinth Disorders

 

Rule of thumb:

 

  • Irritative lesions (hyperactive labyrinth) → nystagmus towards the same side.
  • Destructive lesions (hypoactive labyrinth) → nystagmus towards the opposite side.

 

This happens because the brain interprets imbalance in firing between the two vestibular systems:

 

  • If one side is overactive (irritative) → eyes beat towards that side.
  • If one side is destroyed (hypoactive) → eyes beat towards the opposite, normal side.

 

So, opposite side nystagmus = Purulent + Trauma + Hypoactive.
      Same side nystagmus = Serous (early, irritative).

questions.text: Identify the ethmoidal cells shown in the CT:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Agger nasi

 

  • The CT scan shows air cells located anterior and superior to the nasolacrimal duct, marked by arrows.
  • These are Agger nasi cells, which are the most anterior ethmoidal air cells.
  • They are located just anterior to the attachment of the middle turbinate and are important surgically, as they form the anterior boundary of the frontal recess.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bulla ethmoidalis: 

 

  • The largest and most constant anterior ethmoidal cell.
  • Lies posterior to the uncinate process and forms part of the lateral nasal wall.

 

 

Option B. Concha bullosa:

 

  • Pneumatization of the middle turbinate itself.
  • Seen as an air-filled cavity inside the turbinate, not as anterior ethmoid cells.

 

 

Option D. Haller cell:

 

  • Infraorbital ethmoid air cells, located along the floor of the orbit near the maxillary sinus roof.

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman comes to the office due to several days of right ear pain. This morning she had 2 episodes of dizziness and almost fell. The patient is currently taking trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for an uncomplicated urinary tract infection. She has had no subjective fever, vision loss, or headaches. Temperature is 37⁰C (98.6⁰F), blood pressure is 116/78 mm Hg, and pulse is 100/min. Ear examination reveals several erythematous vesicles in the right external auditory canal with no drainage. The tympanic membrane is visible and intact. There is mild right-sided facial droop. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. Which is the most likely cause of this patient's illness?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Varicella zoster virus

 

This patient has right ear pain, erythematous vesicles in the external auditory canal, dizziness, and ipsilateral facial droop.

 

These findings are classic for Ramsay Hunt syndrome (Herpes zoster oticus):

 

  • Cause: Reactivation of latent Varicella zoster virus in the geniculate ganglion of CN VII.
  • Triad:
    1. Auricular pain + vesicles in ear canal/pinna
    2. Facial paralysis (lower motor neuron type)
    3. Vestibulocochlear symptoms (vertigo, tinnitus, hearing loss)

 

So the most likely cause is Varicella zoster virus.

 

 

Vesicle in the auditory canal and auricle of the patient of Ramsay hunt syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pseudomonas:

 

  • Causes malignant otitis externa (especially in elderly diabetics).
  • Presents with severe ear pain, granulation tissue, sometimes cranial nerve palsies if advanced.
  • But vesicular rash and acute facial droop are not typical.

 

Option B. Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1):

 

  • Causes herpes labialis and occasionally encephalitis.
  • Not associated with vesicles in the ear canal and facial palsy.

 

Option C. Keratosis obturans:

 

  • A benign condition due to accumulation of keratin in the external auditory canal.
  • Causes ear blockage and conductive hearing loss, not vesicles or facial palsy.

questions.text: A person presents with a tongue ulcer persisting for 3 months. Upon examination, a lesion measuring 3.5 cm x 2.5 cm is observed, accompanied by an 8 mm area of hardened tissue. No lymph node enlargement is detected. According to the 8th AJCC guidelines, what stage does this lesion correspond to?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T2

 

(AJCC 8th Edition – Oral Tongue Cancer)

 

Tumor staging is based on greatest dimension + depth of invasion (DOI):

 

  • T1: Tumor ≤2 cm in greatest dimension and DOI ≤5 mm
  • T2: Tumor ≤2 cm with DOI >5 mm and ≤10 mm
      OR Tumor >2 cm but ≤4 cm with DOI ≤10 mm
  • T3: Tumor >4 cm OR DOI >10 mm
  • T4a: Moderately advanced local disease → invasion into adjacent structures (cortex of mandible, maxilla, skin of face, deep muscles of tongue, etc.)

 

Applying to This Case:

 

  • Tumor size = 3.5 × 2.5 cm → largest dimension = 3.5 cm.
  • Area of induration = 8 mm → this corresponds to depth of invasion (DOI = 8 mm).
  • No nodal involvement → N0.

 

Now match with AJCC criteria:

 

  • Tumor is >2 cm but ≤4 cm = qualifies for T2.
  • DOI = 8 mm (≤10 mm) = still fits T2, not T3.

 

So, staging = T2 N0 M0 → Stage II.

questions.text: 25-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of a painless mass in his mouth. The patient has had the mass for many years and has had no growth or other changes in the mass over that time.  The patient smokes a pack of cigarettes a day and drinks 2 or 3 alcoholic beverages on the weekends. Examination of the mass is seen below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's mass?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bone tumor

 

  • The image shows a hard, bony swelling in the midline of the hard palate, consistent with a torus palatinus.
  • Torus palatinus is a benign bony exostosis (outgrowth of bone) on the midline of the hard palate.
  • It is painless, slow-growing, often discovered incidentally, and usually remains stable throughout life.
  • No malignant potential, no relation to infection, and no toxin-mediated process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Toxin mediated:

 

  • Tobacco and alcohol are risk factors for squamous cell carcinoma, not for torus palatinus.
  • This lesion has been stable for years, so malignancy is unlikely.

 

Option C. Malignant transformation: Malignant oral lesions (like squamous cell carcinoma) present with ulceration, pain, bleeding, induration, and progressive growth, unlike this stable painless bony mass.

 

Option D. Viral infection: Viral lesions (eg, HPV warts) would be soft, mucosal, or verrucous, not hard bony outgrowths.

questions.text: A 35-year-old scuba diver presents with sudden onset vertigo, tinnitus, and hearing loss in the right ear after rapidly surfacing from a deep dive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Perilymphatic fistula

 

  • Perilymphatic fistula occurs when there is a tear between the middle and inner ear (oval or round window rupture), leading to leakage of perilymph.
  • Risk factors: Sudden barotrauma, head trauma, weight lifting, diving, forceful Valsalva.
  • Clinical features:
    • Sudden vertigo, tinnitus, sensorineural hearing loss, disequilibrium.
    • Symptoms occur after pressure changes (like diving).
    • Hennebert's Sign: When external pressure is applied to the ear, such as by pressing on the ear canal, this pressure can cause the fluid in the inner ear to move, stimulating the semicircular canals and triggering vertigo. 
    • Tullio Phenomenon: Similarly, sound can also cause pressure fluctuations that travel through the fistula, leading to vertigo. 
  • Management: Bed rest, avoidance of straining; surgery if persistent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Otitis externa: Causes ear pain, discharge, tenderness → not vertigo or acute SNHL.

 

Option B. Vestibular neuritis: Causes vertigo but no hearing loss.

 

Option D. EAC osteoma: Benign, slow-growing, painless → not acute symptoms.

choices.text: It is used for effective ventilation up to 6 hours
It is used to measure central venous pressure
It should be followed by tracheostomy
Work of breathing is more than bag and mask ventilation

questions.text: Following a building collapse, a male patient was brought with copious amount of debris in the mouth. The following procedure was done. Which of the following statements regarding the given procedure is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It should be followed by tracheostomy

 

  • In trauma with airway obstruction (debris, blood, edema), emergency cricothyrotomy is done when endotracheal intubation is not possible.
  • It provides rapid airway access through cricothyroid membrane.
  • But it is temporary (up to ~24–48 hours) because it risks subglottic stenosis.
  • Therefore, it must be followed by a tracheostomy for long-term airway management.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presented with recurrent URTI, poor growth, high-arched palate, and impaired hearing. Tympanogram is given as follows. What would be the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion 

 

The given tympanogram is Type B (flat curve), indicating otitis media with effusion (OME).

 

Key points in the case:

 

  • Child = 6 years old
  • Recurrent URTI
  • Poor growth, high-arched palate (suggesting possible adenoid hypertrophy or cleft palate association)
  • Hearing impairment
  • Tympanogram = Type B (effusion)

 

Management:

 

  • Grommet insertion (ventilation tube) is the standard treatment for persistent OME causing hearing loss.
  • In a 6-year-old child with recurrent URTIs and possible adenoid hypertrophy, the definitive management is adenoidectomy with grommet insertion, because:
    • Adenoid hypertrophy blocks eustachian tube → recurrent OME.
    • Removing adenoids + ventilation tube prevents recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grommet insertion: Effective for effusion, but without adenoidectomy, recurrence is high due to persistent adenoid hypertrophy.

 

Option C. Myringotomy with grommet insertion:

 

  • Myringotomy alone is only for drainage; grommet is placed afterward.
  • Still incomplete without addressing the adenoids in this age group with URTI history.

 

Option D. Myringotomy: Alone is insufficient; effusion reaccumulates within days.

questions.text: A 12-month-old girl is brought to the OPD due to 3 days of fever, rhinorrhea, and nasal congestion. She has no allergies. Both parents smoke cigarettes and both older siblings received tympanostomy tubes as infants. The temperature is 39.4 C (102.9 F). The patient is irritable but easily consoled by her mother. External ear examination is unremarkable, and external ear canals are patent. Otoscopy findings are shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oral antibiotics

 

  • The otoscopic image shows a bulging, erythematous tympanic membrane with loss of normal landmarks, which is classic for acute otitis media (AOM).
  • The child also has fever, irritability, rhinorrhea, and congestion → consistent with bacterial AOM.

 

Risk factors present in this child:

 

  • Exposure to second-hand smoke (both parents smoke).
  • Positive family history (siblings required tympanostomy tubes).
  • Young age (12 months).

 

These all increase the risk of recurrent and severe AOM.

 

Management:

 

  • First-line treatment: High-dose oral amoxicillin (or amoxicillin-clavulanate in resistant cases).
  • Antibiotics are preferred in this case because:
    • Age <2 years.
    • Fever >39 °C (102.9 °F).
    • Severe findings (bulging TM).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Supportive care and observation:

 

  • Sometimes appropriate for older children (>2 years), afebrile, with mild unilateral AOM.
  • Not appropriate here because this is a 12-month-old infant with high fever and severe symptoms.

 

Option C. Temporal CT scan:

 

  • Used only for complications of AOM (mastoiditis, brain abscess, cholesteatoma).
  • Not indicated in a straightforward AOM case.

 

Option D. Tympanocentesis and culture:

 

  • Reserved for refractory or recurrent AOM despite multiple antibiotics, or in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the casualty with a history of choking over a peanut. The child suddenly becomes unresponsive. What would you do as the next step of management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chest compression

 

Step-by-Step Explanation

 

  • The child is 3 years old and has a history of choking on a peanut.
  • Now the child has become unresponsive.

 

Guideline (AHA & PALS for choking):

 

  1. If a child (>2 year) is conscious and choking → abdominal thrusts (Heimlich maneuver).
  2. If an infant (<2 year) is conscious and choking → back blows and chest thrusts.
  3. If the patient becomes unresponsive at any age → start CPR with chest compressions.
    • Chest compressions may help dislodge the foreign body by generating intrathoracic pressure.
    • After every cycle, check the mouth for any visible foreign body and remove it if seen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5 back slaps:

 

  • Only for infants <1 year when conscious. Not for a 3-year-old and not once unresponsive.

 

Option B. Abdominal thrusts:

 

  • Correct if the child is conscious and >1 year old.
  • But not used once the child is unresponsive.

 

Option D. Endotracheal intubation:

 

  • Attempted only after basic life support measures (compressions, clearing visible foreign body).
  • Not the first step.

questions.text: Which of the following will be difficult in the following case?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tracheostomy

 

The chest X-ray provided shows a deviated trachea (pushed to the right side- shown by white arrows) and mediastinal shift, likely suggestive of right sided lung collapse.

 

In such cases, the landmarks of the trachea are distorted and displaced, which makes tracheostomy technically difficult because:

 

  • Trachea is not in its usual midline location.
  • Identifying tracheal rings is challenging.
  • There is increased risk of damaging adjacent structures (vessels, pleura, esophagus).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Laryngeal airway:

 

  • Placement of a supraglottic device (like LMA) is unaffected by tracheal deviation.
  • It is inserted blindly into the pharynx and seals around the laryngeal inlet, so deviation does not hinder.

 

Option C. Endotracheal intubation:

 

  • Intubation via direct laryngoscopy is not usually affected by tracheal deviation, since the trachea is still accessible through the glottis. The tube can still be advanced into the proximal part of trachea.

 

Option D. Cricothyroidotomy:

 

  • This is performed at the level of the cricothyroid membrane, which remains in the midline and is not significantly altered by intrathoracic pathology.
  • Thus, it is not technically difficult in this situation.

choices.text: Steroids are the drug of choice
CROS hearing aid is used in refractory cases

questions.text: All of the following are features of idiopathic sudden SNHL except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) At least for a week

 

Idiopathic Sudden Sensorineural Hearing Loss (SSNHL):

 

  • Defined as rapid onset of hearing loss of more than 30 dB over at least 3 consecutive frequencies
  • Occurring within 72 hours (not over a week)
  • It is an otologic emergency
  • Most cases are idiopathic, though viral, vascular, or autoimmune causes are suspected

 

So the statement “At least for a week” is wrong, since SSNHL must develop within 72 hours, not over a week.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. More than 30 dB hearing loss: Correct, this is part of the definition of SSNHL

 

Option C. Steroids are the drug of choice: Correct, both systemic and intratympanic steroids are standard initial treatment

 

Option D. CROS hearing aid is used in refractory cases: Correct, in cases with persistent unilateral profound hearing loss, CROS (Contralateral Routing of Signal) or Bone Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA) are used for rehabilitation

questions.text: What test is not used for testing olfaction?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arnold stick test

 

Tests of olfaction include Smell diskettes, UPSIT (University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test), and CC-SIT (Cross-Cultural Smell Identification Test).

 

The Arnold nerve (auricular branch of vagus) stimulation produces cough reflex, not smell sensation, hence Arnold stick test is not used for olfaction.

 

Arnold Stick test: Demonstrate Arnold reflex[ear-cough reflex]

 

  • When the ear canal is stimulated (eg with a cotton swab or stick), some patients develop a reflex cough.
  • This happens because sensory input via Arnold’s nerve travels through the vagus → medullary cough center → efferent vagal output to larynx/trachea → cough.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Smell diskettes: Standardized tool to test olfactory function.
 

Option C. UPSIT: Widely used, validated olfactory test.
 

Option D. CC-SIT: Simplified 12-item version of UPSIT for cross-cultural use.

choices.text: Sagittal sinus thrombosis / Sigmoid sinus thrombosis

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with difficulty in opening the mouth and tonic spasms of the limbs. The child gives a history of CSOM. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tetanus

 

  • Tetanus is caused by Clostridium tetani, which produces the neurotoxin tetanospasmin.
  • The toxin enters through wounds or chronic infections like CSOM (middle ear discharge provides an anaerobic environment).
  • The toxin blocks inhibitory neurotransmitters (glycine, GABA) in the CNS.
  • Classical presentation:
    • Trismus (lockjaw) = inability to open mouth due to masseter spasm.
    • Tonic generalized spasms of the body and limbs.
    • Reflex spasms triggered by minor stimuli (light, sound, touch).
  • In this case: CSOM serves as a portal of entry → child develops trismus + tonic spasms → classic for tetanus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Meningitis:

 

  • Presents with fever, headache, vomiting, altered sensorium, and neck rigidity.
  • It does not cause trismus or generalized tonic spasms.
  • Kernig’s and Brudzinski’s signs are typical, not spasmodic episodes.

 

Option C. Bezold abscess:

 

  • Complication of mastoiditis where pus escapes through the mastoid tip into the sternocleidomastoid sheath.
  • Presents with neck swelling below the mastoid, torticollis, and fever.
  • No generalized muscle spasms or trismus.

 

Option D. Sigmoid sinus thrombosis / (lateral sinus thrombosis)

 

  • Another complication of CSOM.
  • Symptoms: persistent fever, headache, papilledema, chills, septicemia.
  • Neurological signs due to venous congestion.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a extrinsic laryngeal membrane?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cricothyroid

 

The extrinsic laryngeal membranes and ligaments are those that connect the larynx to structures outside of it (like hyoid bone, epiglottis, or trachea).

 

  • These include:
    • Thyrohyoid membrane → between thyroid cartilage and hyoid bone
    • Hyoepiglottic ligament → between hyoid bone and epiglottis
    • Cricotracheal ligament → between cricoid cartilage and first tracheal ring

 

The “cricothyroid” given in the options is intrinsic to the larynx. The membrane in this region is the cricothyroid membrane (cricothyroid ligament), which is part of the intrinsic framework and forms the site for emergency cricothyrotomy.

 

Thus, Cricothyroid is not classified as an extrinsic laryngeal membrane.

questions.text: A young lady presented to the ENT OPD with a history of sudden onset unilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, and dizziness following an episode of acute otitis media two weeks back. Rinne test and fistula test were positive. She had refused treatment then and currently came with complaints of worsened hearing loss in the affected ear. On examination, the fistula test was negative. What would be the most likely finding on the Rinne test in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) False negative

 

  • This patient initially had labyrinthine fistula due to acute otitis media → hence positive fistula test (vertigo/nystagmus on pressure over tragus or Siegel’s speculum).
  • With progression and worsening hearing loss, the labyrinth has likely become destroyed/non-functional.

 

Now regarding Rinne’s test:

 

  • In sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL), air conduction (AC) is still better than bone conduction (BC), so Rinne remains positive.
  • But in severe–profound SNHL, the patient may not perceive sound via air conduction at all, but may feel it by bone conduction (due to skull vibrations being sensed by the opposite ear).
  • This makes Rinne appear negative (BC > AC) even though the pathology is sensorineural, not conductive.
  • This phenomenon is called a false negative Rinne test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. True positive: Correct in conductive hearing loss (AC > BC on affected side). Not expected here.

 

Option B. True negative: Would be seen in real conductive hearing loss. Not the case here since pathology is sensorineural.

 

Option C. False positive: Occurs when bone conduction vibrations are picked up by the opposite normal ear (crossover), falsely suggesting a positive Rinne. This is different from our case.

questions.text: Which of the following is enclosed in the investing layer of deep cervical fascia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sternocleidomastoid

 

The investing layer of deep cervical fascia is the most superficial layer of the deep cervical fascia.

 

  • It splits to enclose sternocleidomastoid (SCM) and trapezius muscles.
  • It also forms the roof of the posterior triangle of the neck.
  • It attaches superiorly to the mandible and skull base, inferiorly to clavicle and sternum.

 

Thus, sternocleidomastoid is enclosed in this layer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Esophagus: Enclosed by pretracheal fascia (visceral part), not by investing fascia.

 

Option C. Scalenus anterior: Covered by prevertebral fascia, not by investing fascia.

 

Option D. Nodes of Rouvier: These are retropharyngeal lymph nodes, lying in the retropharyngeal space, not within the investing fascia.

questions.text: Which of the following devices can be used for managing a patient with B/L external auditory canal atresia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 

 

 

The device useful in bilateral external auditory canal atresia is the Bone Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA) (Image A)

 

Let’s analyze each image:

 

Image A– Bone Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA):

 

  • Components: sound processor, titanium abutment, titanium fixture.
  • Works via direct bone conduction.
  • Very useful in bilateral external auditory canal atresia or other conductive hearing loss where ear canal and ossicles cannot be used.

 

Image B– Cochlear Implant:

 

  • External sound processor and internal electrode array inserted into cochlea.
  • Used for severe to profound bilateral sensorineural hearing loss, not for external canal atresia.

 

Image C– Stapes Prosthesis (Piston):

 

  • Used in otosclerosis surgery (stapedotomy).
  • For conductive hearing loss due to stapes fixation, not suitable for canal atresia.

 

Image D– TORP (Total Ossicular Replacement Prosthesis):

 

  • Replaces the ossicular chain when absent/damaged.
  • Used for middle ear reconstruction, not in external canal atresia.

questions.text: 68-year-old woman comes to the office due to oral pain. For the last 3 days, she has had mild pain in the left lower jaw associated with swelling of the gums. The patient had a loose molar extracted 3 weeks ago and the extraction site never completely healed. Medical history is notable for osteoporosis treated with calcium, vitamin D, and zoledronic acid. She has never used tobacco or alcohol. Vital signs are normal. Examination shows gingival edema and erythema surrounding an area of exposed bone at the left lower jaw. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Osteonecrosis

 

  • The patient has osteoporosis treated with zoledronic acid (a bisphosphonate).
  • Bisphosphonates inhibit osteoclast-mediated bone resorption. A well-known complication is osteonecrosis of the jaw (ONJ), especially after tooth extraction or trauma.
  • Features: Pain, swelling, gingival inflammation, exposed necrotic bone that does not heal.
  • Risk factors: IV bisphosphonates (zoledronic acid), tooth extractions, poor oral hygiene.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malignancy: Would present as non-healing ulcer, often with induration, but not any bisphosphonate link.

 

Option B. Herpetic stomatitis: Painful vesicles and ulcers in and around mouth region, not bone exposure.

 

Option C. Mucormycosis: Seen in uncontrolled diabetes, necrotic black eschar in palate/nose, not localized to extraction site with bisphosphonates.

questions.text:
Which of the following are indications of cochlear implant?


a. Congenital hearing loss
b. Otosclerosis
c. Aminoglycoside-induced profound hearing loss
d. Congenital malleus fixation
questions.solution:
Ans. C) a, c

 

Cochlear implant indications:

 

  • Severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss (bilateral), not corrected by hearing aids.
  • Common indications:
    • Congenital profound SNHL → Statement (a).
    • Drug-induced profound SNHL (eg aminoglycosides) → Statement (c).

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

  • Statement b. Otosclerosis: This is a conductive hearing loss due to stapes fixation → best treated with stapedectomy and prosthesis, not cochlear implant.
  • Statement d. Congenital malleus fixation: Again conductive loss, surgical correction is preferred, not implant

choices.text: Apply ice packs to the nose and recommend NSAIDs
Incise and drain the nasal septum

questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to the urgent care clinic after being hit in the face with a basketball. He is currently unable to breathe through his nose.  Oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Examination is given below. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Incise and drain the nasal septum

 

  • The image shows a swollen nasal septum following trauma, consistent with a septal hematoma.
  • A septal hematoma occurs when blood collects between the nasal septal cartilage and its overlying perichondrium.
  • If untreated, it can cut off the blood supply to the septal cartilage, leading to avascular necrosis and permanent deformity such as saddle-nose deformity.
  • Therefore, the best next step in management is immediate incision and drainage of the septal hematoma, followed by packing to prevent re-accumulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Apply ice packs to the nose and recommend NSAIDs:

 

  • Appropriate for simple nasal contusion or minor trauma, but not for septal hematoma.
  • Would delay proper treatment and risk necrosis of septal cartilage.

 

Option B. Embolize the sphenopalatine artery:

 

  • Done in severe or posterior epistaxis refractory to packing.
  • Not indicated for septal hematoma.

 

Option D. Insert anterior nasal packing:

 

  • Used for anterior epistaxis, not for hematoma. Packing without drainage would not resolve the collection and could worsen pressure on cartilage.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is not involved with olfaction?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypoglossal

 

  • The olfactory nerve (CN I) is the main nerve of smell.
  • However, other cranial nerves provide additional sensations that contribute to the perception of odors, often called the “common chemical sense”.
  • Hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) is purely motor to the tongue muscles and has no sensory or chemosensory role, so it is not involved in smell or taste.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Facial / Trigeminal:

 

  • Facial nerve (CN VII): via its chorda tympani branch carries taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, which works together with olfaction to form flavor perception.
  • Trigeminal nerve (CN V): its ophthalmic and maxillary divisions carry sensations of burning, stinging, or cooling in the nasal mucosa (eg ammonia, menthol, chili). These sensations are not pure smell but are perceived as part of the odor experience.

 

Option B. Glossopharyngeal (CN IX):

 

  • Provides taste sensation to the posterior one-third of the tongue.
  • Also contributes some visceral sensory fibers from the oropharynx.
  • These taste sensations integrate with olfactory input centrally, contributing to flavor, so it is indirectly involved in the olfactory experience.

 

Option C. Vagus (CN X):

 

  • Provides visceral sensory input from the pharynx, larynx, and epiglottis, including taste buds at the epiglottis.
  • Chemosensory input from vagus fibers helps detect irritants or taste stimuli in the upper airway, which can influence the overall perception of smell and flavor.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of chronic otitis media presents with a sudden onset of severe hearing loss. Audiometry reveals a conductive hearing loss of 54 dB. Given the levels of normal conversation, what is the patient's level of hearing loss equivalent to in everyday sounds?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Normal conversation

 

Hearing thresholds can be categorized based on decibel levels of everyday sounds:

 

  • Whisper: ~30 dB
  • Normal conversation: ~60 dB
  • Shouting: ~90 dB
  • Discomfort: ~120 dB

 

With a hearing loss of 54 dB, the patient would have difficulty perceiving sounds at a conversational level, as this threshold aligns with the range of normal conversation (~60 dB). This explains why the patient experiences significant hearing impairment in everyday situations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Whisper: Whispering corresponds to ~30 dB. A hearing loss of 54 dB would far exceed this range, making whispers completely inaudible to the patient.

 

Option C. Shout: Shouting typically reaches ~90 dB, which is much louder than the patient’s reported hearing loss threshold of 54 dB. Shouts would still likely be heard by the patient.

 

Option D. Discomfort of the ear: Discomfort occurs at very high sound levels (~120 dB), such as from loud machinery or explosions, which is unrelated to the patient's hearing loss level.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A conductive hearing loss of 54 dB corresponds to the inability to hear normal conversation (~60 dB), significantly affecting communication in everyday situations.

questions.text:
Which of the following are causes of stridor in neonates?


a. Laryngomalacia
b. Subglottic stenosis
c. Recurrent respiratory papillomatosis
d. Hemorrhagic polyp
questions.solution:
Ans. C) a, b

 

Statement a. Laryngomalacia:

 

  • Most common cause of stridor in neonates.
  • Congenital, appears within first 2 weeks of life.

 

Statement b. Subglottic stenosis:

 

  • Can be congenital.
  • Second most common congenital cause of neonatal stridor.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement c. Recurrent respiratory papillomatosis:

 

  • Caused by HPV infection, usually acquired perinatally.
  • Typically presents later (2–5 years of age), not in the neonatal period.

 

Statement d. Hemorrhagic polyp:

 

  • Benign vocal cord lesions, not seen in neonates.
  • More common in older children or adults due to voice abuse.

choices.text: The middle layer of the tympanic membrane is derived from mesoderm and contains radial, circular, and parabolic fibers
The outer epithelial layer is continuous with the skin of the external auditory canal and is derived from ectoderm
The inner mucosal layer is derived from ectoderm and is continuous with the middle ear mucosa
The region called Shrapnell’s membrane does not transmit sound

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding the tympanic membrane are correct, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The inner mucosal layer is derived from ectoderm and is continuous with the middle ear mucosa

 

  1. Outer epithelial layer:
    • Derived from ectoderm.
    • Continuous with the skin of the external auditory canal.
  2. Middle fibrous layer
    • Derived from mesoderm.:
    • Contains radial, circular, and parabolic fibers that provide strength and elasticity.
    • Absent in the pars flaccida (Shrapnell’s membrane).
  3. Inner mucosal layer:
    • Derived from endoderm.
    • Continuous with the mucosa of the middle ear cavity.

 

The incorrect statement in the question is option C, because it wrongly says the inner mucosal layer is from ectoderm. It is actually from endoderm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Middle layer derived from mesoderm and contains radial, circular, and parabolic fibers: Correct. Provides structural support to the tympanic membrane.

 

Option B. Outer epithelial layer continuous with skin of external auditory canal and derived from ectoderm: Correct. The outermost layer is ectodermal in origin.

 

Option D. Shrapnell’s membrane (pars flaccida) does not transmit sound: Correct. Pars flaccida lacks the fibrous middle layer, hence does not contribute to sound conduction.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to persistent nasal congestion and stuffiness. A year ago, she came to the emergency department due to severe wheezing after taking naproxen for menstrual cramping. HRCT of the patient is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C﻿) ﻿Nasal polyposis

 

The patient’s history of severe wheezing after NSAID use and current HRCT showing multiple bilateral soft tissue densities in the nasal cavity points to nasal polyposis. This scenario fits the classic triad of aspirin sensitivity, asthma, and nasal polyps (Samter’s triad).

 

Thus, the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is Nasal polyposis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allergic rhinitis: Often presents on imaging as mucosal thickening and turbinate swelling without the formation of discrete polypoid masses. The inflammatory changes are generally confined to the mucosa and do not cause significant expansion or opacification of the sinus cavities. 

 

Option B. Fungal rhinosinusitis: Particularly the allergic or invasive forms, is characterized on CT by the presence of hyperdense areas representing allergic mucin or fungal elements, frequently accompanied by bone erosion or aggressive sinus expansion.

 

Option D. Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: Is a highly vascular benign tumor, nearly exclusive to adolescent males, presenting with recurrent epistaxis and a soft tissue mass in the nasopharynx, often leading to characteristic anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus (Holman-Miller sign); it is neither typical in adult females nor associated with diffuse nasal or sinus opacification.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with a painless swelling in his right medial face since a few months. The MRI image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mucocele

 

The MRI shows a well-defined, expansile lesion in the right maxillary sinus with characteristic features of fluid retention and sinus expansion without aggressive bone destruction, consistent with a mucocele.

 

The clinical presentation of painless, progressive swelling in the medial face, along with the described MRI findings, most likely represents a Mucocele.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Maxillary sinusitis: Maxillary sinusitis typically presents with signs of infection and mucosal thickening, not expansile cystic lesions.

 

Option C. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a vascular tumor usually affecting adolescent males and arises near the nasopharynx, often with nasal obstruction and epistaxis.

 

Option D. Inverted papilloma: Inverted papilloma is a benign epithelial tumor that commonly shows unilateral nasal obstruction with papillomatous masses but does not cause expansive sinus fluid retention as seen here.

choices.text: It bypasses upper airway structures from nose to larynx thereby reducing the dead space by 50%.
Usually done at the level of 2nd to 3rd tracheal rings.
High tracheostomy (1st ring) done along with surgeries related to cancer larynx.

questions.text: All of the following are true about the device shown below except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) An uncuffed tube is preferred

 

The device shown is a tracheostomy tube. Among the statements, the incorrect one is:

 

An uncuffed tube is preferred.

 

  • Cuffed tubes are usually preferred in adults, especially in needing mechanical ventilation.
  • A cuffed tracheostomy tube prevents aspiration and allows positive-pressure ventilation.
  • Uncuffed tubes are generally used in children (to avoid tracheal injury due to smaller airway diameter) or in long-term weaning once aspiration risk is low.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. It bypasses upper airway structures from nose to larynx thereby reducing the dead space by 50 percent: This is correct. A tracheostomy provides a direct airway into the trachea, bypassing the nasal cavity, oral cavity, pharynx, and larynx. By doing this, it reduces the anatomical dead space by approximately half, which helps improve ventilation efficiency and decreases the work of breathing.

 

Option B. Usually done at the level of 2nd to 3rd tracheal rings: This is correct. The standard site for performing a tracheostomy is between the second and third tracheal rings. This avoids complications of going too high (risk of subglottic stenosis and cricoid injury) or too low (risk of injury to large vessels such as the innominate artery).

 

Option C. High tracheostomy (1st ring) done along with surgeries related to cancer larynx: This is correct. In patients undergoing surgery for laryngeal carcinoma, a high tracheostomy at the first tracheal ring may be done. This helps avoid tumor contamination and allows proper exposure for laryngectomy procedures.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient comes with hoarseness of voice and difficulty swallowing. The patient was diagnosed with laryngeal carcinoma and surgical management was done. The post-operative image of the patient is given below. Which of the following surgery was done on this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Total laryngectomy

 

  • The image shows a permanent stoma in the neck (laryngectomy stoma), with the airway opening directly to the exterior.
  • This is not a temporary tracheostomy (which would have a tube in place and could later be closed).
  • Instead, this is a permanent separation of the airway from the upper respiratory tract, which is done in total laryngectomy.

 

Total laryngectomy:

 

  • Entire larynx (including vocal cords) is removed.
  • Indicated in advanced laryngeal carcinoma.
  • Results in:
    • Permanent tracheostoma (breathing only via stoma, not nose/mouth).
    • Loss of natural voice → patient may require voice rehabilitation (esophageal speech, electrolarynx, or tracheoesophageal puncture prosthesis).

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Partial laryngectomy:

 

  • Preserves part of the larynx and voice.
  • Does not result in a permanent stoma.

 

Option B. Percutaneous tracheostomy:

 

  • Temporary airway access through trachea, usually with a tube in place.
  • Stoma would close after tube removal.

 

Option C. Standard tracheostomy:

 

  • Temporary opening with tube; the upper airway is still connected.
  • Different appearance from a permanent laryngectomy stoma.

questions.text: All of the following are accepted indications for adenoidectomy except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Velopharyngeal insufficiency

 

Adenoidectomy is performed when enlarged adenoids cause persistent symptoms or complications. Accepted indications include:

 

  • Sleep apnea / obstructive symptoms.
  • Chronic serous otitis media (Otitis media with effusion).
  • Recurrent/ chronic sinusitis 

 

Velopharyngeal insufficiency (VPI), on the other hand, is a condition where there is incomplete closure of the velopharyngeal sphincter during speech → leading to hypernasality and nasal air escape.

 

  • Removing adenoids in a child with VPI will worsen the condition, since the adenoids actually help in sealing the velopharyngeal gap.
  • Therefore, VPI is a contraindication to adenoidectomy, not an indication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sleep apnea: Correct indication due to obstruction by hypertrophied adenoids.

 

Option B. Chronic serous otitis media: Correct indication; adenoids interfere with eustachian tube function.

 

Option C. Recurrent sinusitis: Correct indication; infected adenoid tissue contributes to persistent sinus infection.

questions.text: What is the instrument shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Barany noise box

 

The instrument shown in the image is a Barany noise box. It is used in audiological testing to create masking noise, particularly during tuning fork tests to mask the non-test ear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Meniette device: A device used in the treatment of Meniere's disease; it delivers low-pressure pulses through the tympanic membrane to the inner ear to reduce vertigo episodes.

 

 

Option C. Hopkin endoscope: A type of rigid endoscope with rod-lens optics, widely used in ENT and other surgical procedures for better illumination and visualization of internal structures, especially sinus and middle ear.

 

 

Option D. Baron suction: A fine, angled suction tip instrument commonly used in ENT surgeries, especially for suctioning in small spaces like the ear canal and nasal cavity.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with difficulty hearing. MRI with gadolinium contrast shows a 3.5 cm mass in the cerebellopontine angle. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Surgery

 

  • The MRI shows a large cerebellopontine angle mass (arrow).
  • In this clinical context, the most likely diagnosis is a vestibular schwannoma (acoustic neuroma).
  • The patient has a 3.5 cm tumor, which is considered large.

 

Management depends on size and symptoms:

 

<3 cm : Stereotactic radio Sx/gamma knife Sx.

 

>3 cm : Surgical excision 

 

Observation: Suitable for small, asymptomatic tumors in elderly or poor surgical candidates.

questions.text: A 55-year-old diabetic male develops unilateral facial pain and loosening of teeth. MRI is shown below. Which of the following histopathological appearances is most likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aspetate, ribbon shaped hyphae

 

This diabetic patient with unilateral facial pain, loosening of teeth, and the shown MRI and oral findings is most likely suffering from mucormycosis (rhino-orbito-cerebral type). In mucormycosis, histopathology will show broad, aseptate, ribbon-shaped hyphae, which invade blood vessels and tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Septate hyphae: Which are divided by regular cross-walls, are characteristic of Aspergillus species. Under the microscope, Aspergillus shows thin, septate hyaline (light-colored) hyphae with acute angle branching, usually around 45 degrees. This feature helps distinguish it from mucormycosis, which shows broad, aseptate, ribbon-like hyphae.

 

Option C. True yeast: Forms are seen in fungi such as Cryptococcus, which reproduce by budding and typically appear as round or oval cells with a capsule. 

 

Option D. Pseudo-yeast: Or pseudohyphae are elongated yeast cells attached end-to-end, often seen in Candida species, resembling hyphae but with constrictions at septal junctions. Neither true yeast nor pseudo-yeast forms are found in mucormycosis

questions.text: 56-year-old previously healthy man comes to the OPD due to decreased hearing in both ears. He reports difficulty understanding conversations in crowded rooms. For the past 12 years, he has worked in a factory where he has to shout to communicate with coworkers and has seldom worn hearing protection. An audiogram is obtained as shown in the image below. Which of the following is most likely abnormal in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Organ of Corti

 

  • The audiogram shows a bilateral sensorineural hearing loss with a notch at 4 kHz, which is the classic pattern for noise-induced hearing loss (NIHL).
  • The patient has worked in a noisy environment (factory) for years without protection → most consistent with NIHL.

 

Pathophysiology of NIHL:

 

  • Prolonged exposure to loud sounds damages the outer hair cells of the Organ of Corti (especially at the basal turn of cochlea).
  • This produces a characteristic “noise notch” at 4,000 Hz on audiogram.
  • Speech discrimination becomes difficult, especially in noisy environments (difficulty in crowded rooms).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Auditory nerve: Damage would cause sensorineural loss but not specifically the 4 kHz “noise notch.” More typical of retro-cochlear pathology (eg, acoustic neuroma).

 

Option B. Cochlear cupula: Refers to the apex of cochlea, important for low-frequency hearing. NIHL affects basal turn (high frequencies) first, not apex.

 

Option C. Middle ear ossicles: Cause conductive hearing loss, not sensorineural. Audiogram would show an air-bone gap.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department after having a seizure at home. Her mother says that the girl has had a mild headache and fatigue for the past few days. CT scan of the head is shown in the image below. Which of the following historical details is most relevant in establishing this patient's diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Recent episode of otitis media

 

  • The CT scan shows a ring-enhancing lesion with surrounding edema in the temporal lobe.
  • This is classic for a brain abscess.
  • In children, the most common cause is direct extension from infections of the middle ear (otitis media) or mastoiditis → leading to a temporal lobe abscess.
  • Clinical presentation: fever, headache, seizures, focal neurologic signs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Family history of seizures: Relevant for epilepsy, but CT shows a mass lesion (abscess), not  specifically suggestive of primary seizure disorder.

 

Option B. Maternal history of perinatal infection: May be relevant for congenital TORCH infections, but here the acute ring-enhancing lesion points to abscess.

 

Option C. Previous recurrent gingival bleeding: Suggests hematologic disorder (eg, platelet defect), not related to abscess formation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to hearing loss in her right ear. A week ago, the patient developed symptoms of nasal congestion, cough, and rhinorrhea. Three days ago, she traveled from New York to Delhi. On her return flight yesterday, the patient developed hearing loss and severe pain in her right ear and noticed a drop of blood on her finger when she scratched her ear canal. All symptoms have resolved except for persistent hearing loss in the right ear. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Reassurance and follow-up examination

 

The otoscopic image shows a small central perforation of the tympanic membrane with some blood staining. The history is typical of barotrauma-induced tympanic membrane rupture:

 

  • Preceding upper respiratory tract infection → causes eustachian tube dysfunction.
  • Air travel with pressure changes → leads to sudden middle ear pressure imbalance.
  • This results in acute tympanic membrane perforation with pain, bleeding, and hearing loss.

 

Natural Course

 

  • Most traumatic or barotrauma-related tympanic membrane perforations heal spontaneously within a few weeks.
  • Hearing usually recovers as the membrane heals.
  • The correct management is conservative:
    • Keep the ear dry (no water entry).
    • Avoid ear drops unless infected.
    • Follow-up to check healing in 4–6 weeks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aural irrigation: Contraindicated in tympanic membrane perforation, as it risks middle ear infection.

 

Option B. Oxymetazoline: Topical nasal decongestants[alpha agonists] are sometimes used for eustachian tube dysfunction but are not required after a clear perforation has occurred.

 

Option D. Tympanoplasty:

 

  • Surgical repair is indicated only if the perforation persists beyond 2–3 months, or if recurrent infections occur.
  • Not the first step.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0 at 30 weeks gestation, comes to the OPD due to increasing difficulty hearing, especially on the right side. A tuning fork held over the middle of the forehead sounds louder in the right ear. Tuning fork sounds are better heard with bone conduction on the right side and with air conduction on the left. The remainder of the neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D)﻿﻿﻿ Otosclerosis

 

This pregnant woman has progressive conductive hearing loss with tuning fork findings consistent with right-sided conductive deafness.

 

  • Weber test: Lateralizes to the right ear → suggests conductive hearing loss on right side.
  • Rinne test: On right side → BC > AC = negative Rinne (conductive loss). On left side → AC > BC = normal.
  • Clinical history: Young woman, pregnant (hormonal changes accelerate otosclerosis).

 

Otosclerosis is caused by abnormal bone remodeling at the stapes footplate, leading to stapes fixation and conductive hearing loss. Symptoms worsen during pregnancy due to increased hormonal influences.

 

In patients with otosclerosis, the characteristic "Carhart's notch" on an audiogram may reflect worsening hearing during pregnancy, though the precise causal link is debated. This condition involves abnormal bone growth in the middle ear and affects women more often than men.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic otitis media: Causes conductive hearing loss but would typically present with ear discharge, tympanic membrane abnormalities, or recurrent infections. None mentioned here.

 

Option B. Medication ototoxicity:

 

  • Eg, aminoglycosides, cisplatin.
  • Causes sensorineural hearing loss, usually bilateral, not conductive loss.

 

Option C. Ménière disease:

 

  • Inner ear disorder → episodic vertigo, tinnitus, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss.
  • No vertigo in this case and findings are conductive, not SNHL.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with a history of chronic otitis media presents for tympanoplasty. During the surgery, the surgeon finds that both the malleus and incus are absent. According to Wullstein's classification, which type of tympanoplasty is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type III

 

According to Wullstein’s classification of tympanoplasty, the types are categorized based on the extent of ossicular chain involvement and the placement of the tympanic membrane graft:

 

  • Type I: The tympanic membrane graft is placed on an intact and functioning ossicular chain.
  • Type II: The tympanic membrane graft is placed on the incus, with the malleus absent or eroded.
  • Type III: The tympanic membrane graft is placed directly on the stapes head when both the malleus and incus are absent. This reconstructs the sound conduction mechanism to use the stapes as the connection to the inner ear.
  • Type IV: The tympanic membrane graft is placed over the round window to protect it when the stapes is eroded or absent.

 

In this case, with both the malleus and incus absent, the graft is directly placed on the stapes, fitting the criteria for Type III tympanoplasty.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type I: This involves placement of the tympanic membrane graft on an intact and functioning ossicular chain, which is not applicable here as both the malleus and incus are absent.

 

Option B. Type II: This involves graft placement on the incus with the malleus absent or eroded. However, in this case, the incus is also absent, so Type II tympanoplasty does not apply.

 

Option D. Type IV: This involves covering the round window with a tympanic membrane graft when the stapes is eroded or absent, which is not the scenario here as the stapes is present and intact.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Type III tympanoplasty, the tympanic membrane graft is placed directly on the stapes head when both the malleus and incus are absent, as per Wullstein’s classification.

questions.text: Austin’s classification of ossicular chain defects is based on which components?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Malleus handle and stapes suprastructure

 

  • Austin's classification of ossicular chain defects focuses on:
  • Malleus handle (the part of the malleus that connects to the tympanic membrane) and the stapes suprastructure (the upper part of the stapes that connects to the oval window).

 

The classification helps to identify the nature of the defect and determine the surgical treatment approach

choices.text: Pass a catheter through the nares

questions.text: A 1-hour-old boy is evaluated in the newbor nursery for feeding difficulty. He was able to latch and begin feeding but within 1 minute, his face developed a blue tinge. The boy cried, and his color improved.  Chest radiograph is normal. Which of the following is the best next step in evaluation of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D)﻿﻿﻿ Pass a catheter through the nares

 

  • The newborn develops cyanosis while feeding but improves with crying.
  • Key point: Newborns are obligate nasal breathers.
  • When the infant tries to breathe through the nose during feeding, the obstruction leads to cyanosis.
  • Crying forces the infant to breathe through the mouth → color improves.
  • This is classic for choanal atresia (congenital blockage of the posterior nasal apertures).
  • The next best diagnostic step is to pass a soft catheter through each nostril into the nasopharynx.
  • If the catheter cannot be passed, choanal atresia is confirmed.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Draw blood cultures: Would be appropriate if sepsis suspected, but the sudden positional cyanosis relieved by crying is more consistent with choanal atresia, not infection.

 

Option B. Measure blood methemoglobin level: Methemoglobinemia causes persistent cyanosis unresponsive to oxygen, not feeding-related cyanosis.

 

Option C. Obtain an echocardiogram: Needed if congenital heart disease suspected, but the normal chest X-ray and positional cyanosis with crying relief points more towards nasal obstruction.

questions.text: What is the improper pairing between the anatomical limits of lymph nodes and the Level of lymph nodes?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Level 5: Cricoid to suprasternal notch

 

The neck lymph node levels are anatomically defined for staging head and neck cancers and surgical planning.

 

  • Level 1: A is sub mental & B is sub mandibualr
  • Level 2: Upper jugular group → from skull base to hyoid (around upper third of jugular vein, spinal accessory nodes). IIA located anterior to the SPINAL ACCESSORY NERVE and IIB located posterior to it.
  • Level 3: Middle jugular group → from hyoid to cricoid.
  • Level 4: Lower jugular group → from cricoid to clavicle.
  • Level 5: Posterior triangle group → from skull base to clavicle, posterior to sternocleidomastoid, anterior to trapezius.
  • Level 6: Central compartment → from hyoid to suprasternal notch, between carotid sheaths (includes prelaryngeal, pretracheal, paratracheal nodes).

 

Thus, the pairing “Level 5: Cricoid to suprasternal notch” is wrong — that corresponds more to Level 4/6, not Level 5.

questions.text: What is the grade of tympanic membrane retraction shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Grade 2 

 

The image shows a retracted tympanic membrane with the pars tensa pulled inward and the handle of malleus clearly visible, but not adherent to the promontory. This corresponds to Sade’s classification of tympanic membrane retraction.

 

Sade’s Classification of Retraction Pockets:

 

  • Grade 1: Mild retraction, tympanic membrane touches incus or stapes but not fixed.
  • Grade 2: Retraction touches the incus or stapes but not adherent to the promontory. (Seen in this case)
  • Grade 3: Tympanic membrane adherent to the promontory but not fixed.
  • Grade 4: Tympanic membrane completely plastered onto the promontory and immobile.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient presents with decreased hearing in higher frequencies. It was noted that the basilar membrane was affected. Which of the following structures lie near the affected structure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oval window 

 

  • The patient has presbycusis (age-related hearing loss), which classically affects higher frequencies first.
  • In the cochlea, high-frequency sounds are detected at the base of the basilar membrane.
  • The base of the cochlea is located close to the oval window (where the stapes footplate transmits sound vibrations).
  • Therefore, in high-frequency hearing loss, the affected part of the basilar membrane lies near the oval window.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Modiolus:

 

  • The central bony core of the cochlea containing blood vessels and spiral ganglion.
  • Not directly related to the frequency-specific region of the basilar membrane.

 

Option B. Stria vascularis:

 

  • Vascular epithelium along the lateral wall of cochlear duct.
  • Maintains ionic composition of endolymph (esp. K+).
  • Dysfunction causes metabolic SNHL but not specifically base-frequency loss.

 

Option D. Helicotrema:

 

  • Apex of cochlea, where scala tympani and scala vestibuli meet.
  • Responsible for low-frequency hearing, opposite to what is affected first in presbycusis.

questions.text: A 6-month-old child is brought to the clinic with a common cold and the parents give a history of stridor, dyspnea, and intercostal retractions shortly after birth. On examination, you notice that he has biphasic stridor. What is the most probable etiology of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Congenital subglottic stenosis

 

  • The child has stridor, dyspnea, and intercostal retractions since shortly after birth → strongly suggests a congenital cause rather than an acquired one.
  • Biphasic stridor (occurring during both inspiration and expiration) is a hallmark of fixed airway obstruction at the subglottic or glottic level.
  • Congenital subglottic stenosis = narrowing of the airway below the vocal cords (subglottis).
    • It is the third most common congenital airway anomaly after laryngomalacia and vocal cord paralysis.
    • Presents with biphasic stridor soon after birth, worsens with URTI.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laryngomalacia:

 

  • Most common cause of congenital stridor.
  • But stridor is typically inspiratory (not biphasic).
  • Improves with prone position, worse in supine.

 

Option B. Croup (laryngotracheobronchitis)

 

  • Viral illness, acute onset after a few months of age.
  • Stridor is inspiratory, associated with barking cough and fever.
  • Not present since birth.

 

Option C. Respiratory papillomatosis:

 

  • Caused by HPV (types 6, 11).
